Zhang6 1Beijing Normal University at Zhuhai, Zhuhai 519087, China 2Beijing Honest Technology Co., Ltd., Beijing, 100083, China 3Institute of Applied Physics and Computational Mathematics, Beijing 100094, China 4China Institute of Atomic Energy, Beijing, 102413, China 5Center for Nuclear Study, The University of Tokyo, Wako-shi, 351-0198, Japan 6China Nuclear Power Technology Research Institute Co., Ltd., Shenzhen, 518000, China (Dated: February 6, 2025) Approximately 60 years after the Milligan oil drop experiment in 1909, fractionally charged par- ticles (FCPs) were reported to have been discovered in air-shower cores, and the search for FCPs continues to the present day in space, terrestrial and underground experiments. In this letter, rela- tivistic FCPs are examined as lightly ionizing particles in underground direct detection on the basis of electron recoil data from XENON-nT. For FCPs from supernova shocks, the best results are ob- tained via direct detection, excluding the FCP charge of �3.6 × 10−9 −1.0 × 10−2 ·e corresponding to an FCP mass of 1 keV–556 GeV. For FCPs from general sources, the best limit is achieved, which is far ahead of other results in almost the entire parameter space, by excluding the FCP flux of �4.0 × 10−4 −4.0 × 10−16 cm−2· s−1· sr−1 corresponding to the FCP charge of �1 × 10−6 −1  · e. Introduction. In 1909, Millikan obtained a precision measurement of the charge of an isolated ion and denoted the test value of an elementary charge as e [1, 2]. How- ever, electric charge quantization is currently a mystery that is unexplained by the standard model (SM) of par- ticle physics. In 1969, McCusker and Cairns reported a track in a delayed-expansion Wilson cloud chamber pro- duced by a fractionally charged particle (FCP, denoted “χ”; also known as a “milli- or minicharged particle”) in an air-shower core [3]. Moreover, some difficult prob- lems, such as dark matter (DM) [4] and neutrino oscilla- tions [5, 6], suggest that there must be some new physics beyond the SM. Some researchers have made great efforts to study un- confined and free FCPs (in contrast to the quark’s bound state) to extend the SM. Finding FCPs is helpful in test- ing some popular hypotheses, such as DM [7–10] and string theory [9, 11, 12], as well expanding the SM. In this work, we search for FCPs as lightly ionizing particles (LIPs) with 1.16 ton·year exposure data obtained from the XENON-nT experiment [13] and update the limit on their parameter space. Note that it is currently difficult to determine whether these FCPs are generated in the atmosphere or in outer space. Thus, we search for incident FCPs from general sources (including the atmosphere, the Sun and so on) in the view of the detector and mark them with the sub- script “gen”. Some studies have also attempted to gen- erate FCPs via SM particle interactions in nuclear reac- tors [14, 15] and accelerators [16, 17]. In addition, FCPs in dark cosmic rays can be produced through supernova shock (SNS) and accelerated by the Fermi mechanism. Then, they can undergo radiative cooling, Coulomb scattering and energy redistribution during transport [18–21]. Finally, they reach the Earth, and their flux in the unit of (GeV−1 · cm−2 · s−1 · sr−1) can be estimated via Eq. 1, which is derived from a com- parison with protons [22]. dϕχ dEχ SNS ≈30 · f 1.7 χ · m−1 χ · E−2.7 χ (1) where mχ is the FCP mass in units of GeV; Eχ is the FCP energy in units of GeV; fχ is defined as fχ ≡Qχ/e; Qχ is the charge carried by an FCP; and 0 < fχ < 1.
